Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2021.04.08]RI dev into main" (#8514) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "In search of a guide for upgrading self-hosted NuGet Gallery server" (#8509) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
First, please forgive my newbiness when it comes to installing, configuring and upgrading a self-hosted NuGet Gallery server.

With that said, we have a NuGet Gallery server currently running version 1.0.0-master that was initially setup and configured a few years back by someone who is no longer with our company.  We want to upgrade to the latest and greatest release version, but cannot seem to find any documentation or "how to" guide on performing the upgrade. We are hosting on a Windows 2016 server with IIS and found a couple of links on initial setup, including the "[Hosting the NuGet Gallery Locally in IIS](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/wiki/Hosting-the-NuGet-Gallery-Locally-in-IIS)" wiki page, but don't see anything related to upgrading an existing instance, so any help or direction would be gratefully appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your support.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Installation instructions for NUKE" (#8511) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi everyone! I'm basically following up on another recent proposal to extend the installation instruction tabs.

## Proposal

NUKE provides a `nuke :add-package <package-id> [package-version]` command via our [global tool](https://www.nuget.org/packages/nuke.globaltool), which allows installing packages to the build project. The command works from any directory of a repository built with NUKE, thus covering more situations compared to the conventional `dotnet add` command. More importantly, though, it automatically determines _how_ a package should be installed, which is either as `PackageReference` (regular libraries) or `PackageDownload` (tool packages). The latter is a great feature (thanks once more @nkolev92), because it allows a build to reference tools without messing with references (implicit `ExcludeAssets`), and works with tools in different versions (`PackageReference` wouldn't allow that even with `ExcludeAssets`).

We would like to display this command as installation instructions under a separate "NUKE" tab. Today, users naturally use `PackageReference` instead of `PackageDownload`, which often completely breaks the compilation of the build project, and overall _is_ a sub-optimal approach.

## Listing Criteria

Regarding if we meet the criteria, here are my comments:

- Signification adoption in .NET community: currently at 1.2 million downloads
- Actively maintained and updated: the project is continuously maintained for the last 4 years (since its creation), and as mentioned used by a wide range of companies and projects
- Security compliance: We have repeatable builds. Publish signed packages. Have a package prefix reservation. And 2FA for NuGet.org!

## Background

[NUKE](https://nuke.build) is a build automation system, which is created with the idea to integrate with other .NET tools natively. That means it uses regular C# projects for the build implementation and thus comes with IDE integration out-of-the-box, including navigation, refactoring, and debugging. It is well adopted with almost 1k downloads per day, and many companies and projects actively using and transitioning to it (e.g. OctopusDeploy, JetBrains, AvaloniaUI, ASP.NET Boilerplate, CsvHelper, FluentAssertions, HotChocolate).

---

We and our users would really appreciate for this proposal to be accepted! üôè

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add an ENV Variable for Package Signing Verification on .NET 5+ Linux/MAC" (#10742) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | dotnet.exe):

Product version: 

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: N/A

## Repro steps and/or sample project

Add an environment variable to opt-in to the package signing verification on .NET 5. 
Env var name is `DOTNET_NUGET_SIGNATURE_VERIFICATION` and to enable it set value to `TRUE`. Please note both env var name and value are case sensitive, must to all capital letters. 
This is to provide an opt-in / troubleshooting experience for Mac/Linux based on the reversion of:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3979
We intend this ENV for testing and don't guarantee compatibility.

### Verbose Logs

<!-- Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...) -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "`NuGetProjectManagerService` calls to get installed packages & transitives should batch projects" (#10740) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | Visual Studio | MSBuild.exe | dotnet.exe): VS

Product version: all

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 

## Repro steps and/or sample project

<!-- Please add as much details as possible to help us to reproduce your problem. -->
The following methods are called repeatedly for each project, rather than batched:
```
IProjectContextInfoExtensions.GetInstalledPackagesAsync(this IProjectContextInfo projectContextInfo, projectContextInfos,,)
->
NuGetProjectManagerService.GetInstalledPackagesAsync(IReadOnlyCollection<string> projectIds,)
```
and
```
IProjectContextInfoExtensions.GetInstalledAndTransitivePackagesAsync(this IProjectContextInfo projectContextInfo,)
->
NuGetProjectManagerService.GetInstalledAndTransitivePackagesAsync(IReadOnlyCollection<string> projectIds,)
```

Batching these may save significant overhead in common PM UI actions, and reduce the overall load times for any Tab, event, or action that triggers them (eg, loading of any of the 4 tabs, all Package Management buttons, selecting a package, changing sources, external changes to project).

Related to https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/10356.

### Verbose Logs

<!-- Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...) -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "INuGetProjectService.GetInstalledPackagesAsync throws when MSBuildProjectExtensionsPath is not set" (#10739) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | Visual Studio | MSBuild.exe | dotnet.exe): Visual Studio

Product version: 16.8 - 16.9

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: New API in 16.8

## Repro steps and/or sample project

<!-- Please add as much details as possible to help us to reproduce your problem. -->

### Verbose Logs

<!-- Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...) -->

VS extensions using NuGet's `INuGetProjectService.GetInstalledPackagesAsync` will get an exception if the project being queried is a non-SDK style csproj, but the project is customized so that the MSBuild property `MSBuildProjectExtensionsPath` is not set.

This goes against the API's documentation which says that a result with status `ProjectInvalid` should be returned.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Suggestion] VS should not show redundant warning ‚ÄúPackage ‚Äòxxxxx‚Äô does not exist in folder xxx\xxx‚Äù" (#10207) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.9.0.6947
VS Version: Main\30629.155
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-19h2
## Detailed repro steps
1. Launch VS and click ‚ÄúCreate a new project‚Äù button in the G2C dialog.
2. Create a project such as ASP.NET Web Site (Razor v3) and open the project PM UI.
3. Go to the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab and install a package ‚ÄúCastle.Core‚Äù.
4. Uninstall the package ‚ÄúCastle.Core‚Äù.
## Expected
No redundant warning show in Error List window.
## Actual
The redundant warning ‚ÄúPackage ‚Äòxxxxx‚Äô does not exist in folder xxx\xxx‚Äù show in Error List window as below. Of course it does not exist since it is uninstalled. So there is no need to show the redundant warning like that.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/97712966-22079300-1afa-11eb-81f9-ec985b0f3011.png)
## Note
It start to repro from Dev\5.8.0.6741.

In the meantime, check https://status2.azure.com/ for Azure updates and find work-arounds in this thread https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8480.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Notice: NuGet Restore Failures on Linux distributions using NSS or Mozilla root CA list" (#56) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## Context

Users of .NET 5.0+ will receive error messages when running `dotnet restore` on Linux distros that use [nss](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/) or `ca-certificates` packages maintained by Mozilla's root CA list. The root cause is due to the certificate used for signed NuGet packages recently expiring and as a result the validation for packages uses a timestamp provider chain that has a root certificate that has been [removed by Network Security Services (NSS)](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1686854) which is a popular alternative to [OpenSSL](https://github.com/openssl/openssl).

- [NuGet Microsoft Author Signing Certificate Update](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update/) - Expires January 27th, 2021
- [NuGet.org Repository Signing Certificate Update](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/) - Expires April 14th, 2021

For more information, please read the [Distrust of Symantec TLS Certificates](https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2018/03/12/distrust-symantec-tls-certificates/) on the Mozilla Security Blog, [Mozilla Root Store Policy](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/about/governance/policies/security-group/certs/policy/) on Mozilla.org, and [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues) on the Mozilla Wiki Page.

## Affected Environments

.NET 5.0+ SDK on Linux distros that use [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes). 

At this time, we are not sure of every distro that may be affected. If you're aware of an affected distro, please let us know!

Below is a table that includes .NET support for Linux distros:

### Linux

OS                                    | Version               | Affected          |
--------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------|
[Alpine Linux][Alpine]                | N/A                 | ‚ùì |
[CentOS][CentOS]                      | N/A                    | ‚ùì |
[Debian][Debian]                      | N/A                    | ‚ùì |
[Fedora][Fedora]                      | N/A                   | ‚ùì |
[Linux Mint][Linux-Mint]              | N/A                   | ‚ùì |
[openSUSE][OpenSUSE]                  | N/A                   | ‚ùì |
[Red Hat Enterprise Linux][RHEL]      | N/A                    | ‚ùì |
[SUSE Enterprise Linux (SLES)][SLES]  | N/A               | ‚ùì |
[Ubuntu][Ubuntu]                      | N/A   | ‚ùì |

[Alpine]: https://alpinelinux.org/
[CentOS]: https://www.centos.org/
[Debian]: https://www.debian.org/
[Fedora]: https://getfedora.org/
[Linux-Mint]: https://linuxmint.com/
[OpenSUSE]: https://opensuse.org/
[RHEL]: https://www.redhat.com/en/technologies/linux-platforms/enterprise-linux
[SLES]: https://www.suse.com/products/server/
[Ubuntu]: https://ubuntu.com/

Additionally, here is a table of other Linux variants that may be affected but are not officially supported by .NET.

OS                                    | Version               | Affected       |
--------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------|
[Arch Linux](https://archlinux.org/)                          | 20210328+                 | ‚úÖ[Issue](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10695)             |
[Artix Linux](https://artixlinux.org/)                         | 20201128+                    | ‚úÖ[Issue](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10684)             |

### Other Linux distros

- At the time of writing, we believe other distributions will not be affected until a distribution is updated to include [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes).

## Mitigation

### .NET Core 3.1

.NET 5 introduces a signing verification mechanism that promotes warnings to throw an error at `dotnet restore` time. To work around this, you can temporarily target against .NET Core 3.1.

### Modify CA Certificate Store

Depending on your Linux distro, you can modify your CA certificate store by taking on an earlier version of your `ca-certificates` package.

For reference, the affected version is [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes). `nss` includes a hard-coded list of trusted CA certificates and therefore can be modified to include and trust the `Verisign Universal Root Certificate Authority` again.

Many Linux distros can leverage `dpkg-reconfigure` to check for the entry and enable trust for it. As a manual workaround, you may need to remove a `leading !` from the certificate line & update your CA certificates package.

**Note:** Doing this is considered a bad security practice & should only be done if you understand the security implications of doing so.

## Solution

Due to existing issues with the .NET 5 signing verification feature & fallback of timestamp verification, we have decided to revoke this feature for Unix-based systems within .NET 5 SDK. Therefore your experience of using `dotnet restore` will remain largely the same as it was in .NET Core 3.1. Stay tuned for an updated .NET SDK version that will include this change.

### Stay updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We will also continue posting updates on [NuGet Status](https://status.nuget.org/) and [@NuGet on Twitter](https://twitter.com/nuget).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Custom V2 OData queries will be deprecated March 9th, 2021 " (#54) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (#37) last year and conducted a dry run of the deprecation to ensure that there are no surprises for users (#40). 

We will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in March 9, 2021, as detailed in [the blogpost here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/custom-v2-odata-queries-will-be-deprecated-march-9-2021/).

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post.](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021" (#53) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by March 15th, 2021 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/
